post.title: New York can do better than just free buses
post.subtitle: High (opportunity) costs and a lost opportunity to think bigger on transportation
post.description: Politicians have floated fare-free buses as a proposal to alleviate cost of living and deliver better transit. But look a little closer, and you'll see that free buses and their immense opportunity costs rob the city of a chance to be more ambitious on public transit expansion. I interviewed dozens of New Yorkers and a leading economist to find out more.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The wrong way to decriminalize sex work
post.subtitle: And what Mamdani might do, if elected
post.description: Simply turning a blind eye to the practice without consideration of spill-over effects on local communities and the abuse that exists within the industry won't help New York. The city must learn from jurisdictions that move the practice off the streets, provide regular health screenings, and target human trafficking.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Here's How New York Voters Are Feeling About the Mayoral Race
post.subtitle: Public safety and the cost of living are some of their top concerns
post.description: As the 2025 New York mayoral race heats up, I went on the ground to hear from the candidates themselves and examine what policy proposals might mean for the city.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: American Universities, Two Years After October 7
post.subtitle: City Journal Podcast
post.description: What does a university’s response to terror reveal about its values and its influence on society? On the two-year anniversary of Hamas’s October 7 attacks on Israel, Stu Smith, Neetu Arnold, Adam Lehodey, and Rafael Mangual reflect on national and global reactions to the attacks, especially on American university campuses. Their conversation explores the ideological influence of faculty and campus activism that blurred the line between academic freedom and lawlessness. They also consider how federal funding and institutional incentives shape university behavior.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Here's What Rent Control Looks like in New York City
post.subtitle: The policy degrades the housing stock, distorts the market, and inhibits new development
post.description: Behind the headlines and catchy campaign slogans is a policy that in fact overlooks the fundamental workings of the economics of housing, resulting in worse housing for a higher costs. Read more in City Journal.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: This Decarceration Agenda Would Spell Disaster for New York City
post.subtitle: A plan that Zohran Mamdani once backed raises questions about public safety
post.description: Though socialists have long had prison reform and abolition on the agenda, focusing solely on absolute head-counts risks overshadowing the broader conversation on public safety.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: PAN-GAIA
post.subtitle: Narratives of a Grand Vision
post.description: floating in a galaxy, far far away from the center of where it all started, is a little dot called Planet Earth. PAN-GAIA is an experimental piece of writing capturing the experience of its eight billion inhabitants. THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Government-Run Grocery Stores? These New Yorkers Are Skeptical
post.subtitle: Analysing Mamdani's Proposals
post.description: Zohran Mamdani claims his city-run supermarket proposal would lower prices, but small-business owners and their customers see it as a dubious and costly proposition. Read my analysis of the conversations I had with New Yorkers in City Journal.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: New York City Landlords Are Trapped in Housing Court Hell
post.subtitle: Urgent Reforms are Needed
post.description: A dysfunctional system has created a nightmare for small property owners, with cases dragging on for years and costs piling up. I spoke to New Yorkers affected by these delays to understand how they are being affected and what needs to change.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Choreographing a renewed Euro-American relationship
post.subtitle: What the future could look like
post.description: Now at a crossroads, Europe and America must unite to advance human flourishing and overcome global problems. Read my winning essay to the 2025 SciencesPo American Foundation's essay contest, below.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Eric Adams' Misguided Tax Relief Plan
post.subtitle: Shifting the tax-burden won't alleviate New York's problems
post.description: New York City already has some of the highest tax burdens in the United States. Yet its reliance on the minority of highest earners, coupled with proposals to further shift the tax burden, could backfire.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Are we spiralling into a new Dark Age?
post.subtitle: Analysis and review of Jacobs' Dark Age Ahead
post.description: 'Society shows signs of rushing headlong into a dark age,' writes Jane Jacobs in Dark Age Ahead. But are we really? This essay is an extensive analysis of the good, the bad, and the constructive from Jacobs final work.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Law, Liberty and the Limits of Selfhood
post.subtitle: On the relationship between self and state
post.description: This paper - published in the Brown Journal of Philosophy explores many topics, from the nature of the self, justifications for state action, and consent of the governed. It coalesces around the central research question of whether the state has the right to protect individuals from themselves.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Cities and the Wealth of Nations
post.subtitle: A manual for urban policymakers
post.description: Urban policymakers should focus on cultivating import-replacement as a means of growing their cities. Explore lessons from Jacobs' Cities and the Wealth of Nations in this piece below.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Morte e Vida de Grandes Ciudades, revisitado
post.subtitle: A Portuguese republication
post.description: [Portuguese translation and republication and of my The Death and Life of Great American Cities, Revisited essay] Uma exploração das ideias influentes de Jacobs e seu potencial para abordar os desafios urbanos de hoje e melhorar a vida nas cidades.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: From Wealth to Well-Being
post.subtitle: Critical review of Amartya Sen's Development as Freedom
post.description: Development as Freedom - Amartya Sen's magnum opus, transformed how we view progress. By re-conceptualising development as freedom, economists and politicians shift their focus on to the basic goods that really matter: education, democracy, and civic equality.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Lessons from The Economy of Cities
post.subtitle: Looking back at Jane Jacobs' seminal work
post.description: In the Economy of Cities, Jacobs starts with a provocative claim: that the city in fact proceeds agriculture. From here, she shows how the city is the essential and basic unit of the growth of our civilisation.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The Death and Life of Great American Cities, Revisited
post.subtitle: In defence of the city
post.description: Jane Jacobs' The Death and Life of Great American Cities, published in 1961, revolutionised urban theory. This essay kicks off a series exploring Jacobs' influential ideas and their potential to address today's urban challenges and enhance city living.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Free Speech is Alive and Well at Columbia
post.subtitle: Just look around you.
post.description: There's reason for hope! Free speech isn't dead at Columbia University, in fact it's alive and well, as evidence all around us shows. Explore my thoughts in the Columbia Sundial below.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Andy Warhol and the Masterpiece of Consumption
post.subtitle: Capturing an epoch
post.description: In a world where Andy Warhol is synonymous with contemporary art and a single one of his paintings sells for hundreds of millions of dollars, it is hard not to have an opinion on his work. My goal: to make the case that Warhol's works are indeed masterpieces of art...
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Government, tech, and the outsourcing of virtue
post.subtitle: Virtue cannot be abdicated to the state
post.description: In response to social media addiction, substance abuse and obscene online content, we increasingly look to government and big-tech to regulate excess. Yet this abdication of virtue to government cannot continue and will have very dangerous consequences if it does.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The Case for Virtue
post.subtitle: Striving for excellence and balance
post.description: In choosing virtue, one opens the door to a fuller, more complete and fulfilling life. This essay is an unapologetic defence of Aristotelian virtue.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Decoding the Self
post.subtitle: An exploration through Paul Auster's City of Glass
post.description: What does it mean to be yourself? The answer is more than just the physical - the self is a narrative that one creates around their life, constantly shifting and evolving over time. Below I explore this theme through the lens of Paul Auster's City of Glass.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Voyage to another country: L.P Hartley's The Go Between
post.subtitle: Analysis and notes
post.description: If the past is 'a foreign country,' L.P. Hartley's The Go-Between is a first class ticket on that voyage. Read my notes and analysis on Hartley's acclaimed novel.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Morocco and notes as a global citizen
post.subtitle: Memories from an amazing trip
post.description: I wanted a reminder of the endless possibilities of life; an adventure and a radically different experience. In Morocco, I found all of these things.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Into the complex world of Mrs Dalloway
post.subtitle: Critical analysis of Woolf's masterpiece
post.description: 'What Virginia Woolf created, in Mrs Dalloway, is not so much a novel but a rich canvas of life in post-World War I London.' Explore the context, ideas and impacts of Woolf's seminal work.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Lessons from the twentieth century for the twenty-first
post.subtitle: A re-examination of events.
post.description: It may be almost a quarter of a century since the twentieth century drew to a close and we crossed over into the then unknown frontier of the twenty first, though a careful examination of history reveals that many of the origins of today's problems can be found in the twentieth century.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Towards the metaverse
post.subtitle: The next frontier?
post.description: The metaverse has been hyped. A lot. This long-read essay collection, a collaboration with other students for a class project, explores the nature, potential, and opportunities that the metaverse presents.
post.author: Adam Lehodey et al.

post.title: A world where only money matters
post.subtitle: Comparative analysis of Ellis' American Psycho and Amis' Money
post.description: We live in a world of hyper-consumption, constantly defining ourselves by our position relative to others and the extent to which we consume. An analysis of these two important works of literature gives us a gimpse of the implications of this.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The troubled foundations of Rishinomics
post.subtitle: Sunak's leadersip plan contains many flaws
post.description: A successful political campaign has two ingredients: (1) a message that is coherent, and (2) a message that is sound. Unfortunately for Rishi Sunak, 'Rishinomics' delivers on neither of these...
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: On the road: stories from an American adventure
post.subtitle: Memories from the summer
post.description: Travelling, including 2000 miles of hitchhiking, across the United States for the past few weeks has been an incredibly eye-opening experience. I have had so many adventures, heard so many stories, and met so many great people, that I decided to document it all in writing.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Politics: when it works and when it doesn't
post.subtitle: On the merits and demerits of political decision making
post.description: Political decision making appeals to activists, politicians and voters because it is quick and visible. Yet if we are to continue living in a free and open society, it is essential that we examine the merits and demerits of political decision making.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Critique of Debt: the first 5000 years
post.subtitle: This popular book has many flaws
post.description: I was previously unacquainted with the field of 'economic anthropology,' and it was therefore with interest that I picked up David Graeber's 'Debt: the first 5000 years.' Read my thoughts and critiques below.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Billionaires have the right to exist
post.subtitle: Claudia Webbe's attack on billionaires is baseless
post.description: Claudia Webbe, the Member of Parliament for Leicester East, recently restated her dislike for billioniares in a series of tweets. Her comments are underpinned by a number of fallacies.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Tender is the Night
post.subtitle: Analysis, thoughts and ideas
post.description: The sprawling and complex novel explores mental illness, the ephemerality of our experiences, but also the metamorphosis of individual relationships. For me, it is Fitzgerald's best work.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Fracking can play an important role in lowering energy costs
post.subtitle: The Government should revisit its policy on hydraulic fracturing
post.description: When energy costs rise, people feel the hit directly. Not only do their own energy bills go up, but so too does the price of food, electronics, and almost all other goods. Hydraulic fracturing could be the answer.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: A Letter to Great Britain
post.subtitle: An incredible place.
post.description: There is no greater pleasure than returning home to a place you love. For me, that is Great Britain, the place of dreams and opportunity...
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Levelling up risks becoming Levelling Down
post.subtitle: There are flaws to the Government's current policy
post.description: We are at risk of 'levelling up' becoming a proxy for one set of vested interests grabbing resources at the expense of everyone else.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Veblen's Theory of the Leisure Class
post.subtitle: Summary, Notes and Critiques
post.description: Consumption is driven by a desire to illustrate power and status. This is the important takeaway of Veblen's Theory of the Leisure Class which completely transforms how one views human decisions. Along with this summary of Veblen's work, I analyse how society has changed and in what ways these ideas apply.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: History and Identity
post.subtitle: Exploring the complex links between them
post.description: The trouble with history is, of course, that we can't study everything. What we choose to study or not to study matters immensely - it one of the foundations for our identities.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: American Psycho
post.subtitle: Bret Easton Ellis on the American Dream
post.description: Forceful and raw, Bret Easton Ellis' American Psycho certainly left its mark upon society. To call this work of literature violent would be an understatement. Yet to some extent, it's as if this was not a fictional story but a mirror held up to the societies in which we live.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Rights, Freedom, and the Welfare State
post.subtitle: All rights are based on a social contract
post.description: Does a gazelle have a 'right' not to be eaten by a lion? No - because rights are things we have created, based on a social contract. Here, I explore the relationship between rights, freedom, and the welfare state.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: On the creation of wealth
post.subtitle: Wealth and money are often conflated, but very different
post.description: The origins of wealth are often misunderstood. Many believe the only way to become wealthy is to exploit or take that wealth from somebody else. Yet this premise is deeply flawed.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The Conservatives' worrying move away from economic liberalism
post.subtitle: The way forward: markets and trade
post.description: To truly deliver on the 'levelling-up' agenda and create opportunities for all, the choice is clear: we must embrace trade, markets, and the freedom to choose.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Tyranny can't stop climate change
post.subtitle: The troubling rise of neo-luddism
post.description: Building a better, greener and cleaner world to enable us to live meaninfully and enjoy our lives will require co-operation and depend on technology. It can't be solved by coercion.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: American Dream
post.subtitle: How to live the good life
post.description: What is the American Dream? The embodiment of hope and opportunity, or a failed idea swallowed up by Corporate America?
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Postcard from Mexico City
post.subtitle: La vida está buena.
post.description: México, mi amor. It's a city full of life, of spirit, of joy. Se puede vivir, no sólo existir. Here, one feels the richness, the wholeness, of our existence, in all its splendour.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: We must wake up to Britain's disastrous policy on cannabis
post.subtitle: Prohibition has always done more harm than good.
post.description: The clash between reality and the ideal is not a new one. It is present throughout history, and in all aspects of life and culture. In contemporary Britain, nowhere has this done more harm than in the current policy on the prohibition of marijuana...
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: US Elections: There's a Lot to be Optimistic About
post.subtitle: A turning point in US politics
post.description: It's official: Biden has won the US election and is set to become the 46th President of the USA. Although America remains divided, there are many reasons to be optimistic, and his Presidency could mark the start of a new era in US and international politics.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Long Live Liberalism!
post.subtitle: Despite its flaws, it's still the best system we've got.
post.description: When a wave of populism swept through the world in the mid-2010s, some considered liberalism to be dead. Whilst not all the predictions made about liberalism's fate came true, the Coronavirus is undoubtedly the greatest challenge it has faced since World War II.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Education reform is the key to social mobility
post.subtitle: Social mobility in the 21st Century
post.description: Such a large part of social mobility and equality of opportunity lies in education, that we need to ask ourselves how best to improve the system to tap into the full potential of the thousands of children going through it each year.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: How to reinvigorate our cities
post.subtitle: Build back better.
post.description: With with thousands of city workers being ordered to work from home when the coronavirus pandemic hit, our use of land has changed drastically. In light of this, it is worth assessing why we live in cities in the first place, and what the future challenges will be.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Why vaping could be a silver bullet
post.subtitle: The evidence looks promising.
post.description: If we are serious about improving our health outcomes after coronavirus, it is essential that we take action to combat nicotine-related deaths. Fortunately, we already have the answer: e-cigarettes.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: The History and Future of Smoking
post.subtitle: LONG READ: Examining the roots and next steps.
post.description: It's the largest preventable cause of death, amounts to millions of hours of lost productivity, and costs our health systems billions. Where did it start, why is it actually bad for you, and how can we end nicotine related deaths for good?
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Inequality in a Meritocratic World
post.subtitle: How to reconcile the two?
post.description: Inequality poses numerous problems: social unrest, the rise of extremist parties, and some would say, moral issues. How to deal with the problem of inequality in an increasingly meritocratic world? What does meritocracy even mean?
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: Inside Amazon
post.subtitle: Taking a look inside one of the tech world's largest giants.
post.description: In November 2019, I toured Amazon's second largest Fulfilment Centre (FC). Upon arrival, it felt like I had teleported to the year 2100...
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: On Minimalism, Part Two
post.subtitle: Digital Minimalism
post.description: How can appyling the philosophy of minimalism to our digital lives improve our productivity and make us happer and better people? explore the ideas of 'Digital Minimalism' in this article.
post.author: Adam Lehodey

post.title: On Minimalism, Part One
post.subtitle: There's a better alternative to the way we live.
post.description: Minimalism is not about owning a set number of items. It is about mindfulness, focussing on what truly matters, and not being constrained by material possessions....
post.author: Adam Lehodey
